1.title_api: Hamilton Tiger-Cats edge Edmonton Eskimos on final-play field goal
1.desc_api: Jeremiah Masoli threw for a whopping 419 yards and the Tiger-Cats, after being plagued by early mistakes, scored the last 15 points to win the kind of games that have often slipped away from them this season.
1.caption_api: Ticats’ Luke Tasker shakes Edmonton players as he heads to the end zone for a touchdown to bring the game to withing two points at 24-22. A last-second field goal would tip the game in the Ticats’ favour.

2.title_api: Ticats rally for 25-24 home win over Eskimos
2.desc_api: Hamilton Tiger-Cats rally for 25-24 home victory over Edmonton Eskimos
2.caption_api: Hamilton Tiger-Cats kicker Lirim Hajrullahu kicks the winning field goal to win the game against the Edmonton Eskimos during the second half of CFL football action in Hamilton, Ontario onThursday August 23, 2018. THE CANADIAN PRESS/Mark Blinch

3.title_api: The C.J. Gable revenge game: Ticats running back returns with Esks
3.desc_api: GAME DAY: Thursday, 7:30 p.m. at Tim Hortons Field
3.caption_api: C.J. Gable is pursued by B.C. Lions’ Anthony Orange and Jordan Herdman on Aug. 9. Gable faces his old team in Hamilton Thursday.

4.title_api: Ticats would rather take a bye on bye weeks
4.caption_api: C.J. Gable, No. 2, is expected to be back in the Edmonton Eskimos lineup Thursday in Hamilton.

5.desc_api: Calgary stands a good chance of bouncing back from its first loss when it visits the Tiger-Cats, who are coming off of their bye.

16.title_api: Four-way tie for lead at Northern Trust as Woods stalls
16.desc_api: Sean O’Hair, who needs to play well to continue his season, shared the lead after 18 holes with Kevin Tway, Jamie Lovemark and Vaughn Taylor, while Tiger Woods was five shots back after an even-par 71.
16.caption_api: After a rough start off the tee, Tiger Woods wound up hitting nine of 14 fairways while opening with an even-par 71 at the Northern Trust golf tournament Thursday in Paramus, N.J.

21.title_api: First-round draft pick Will Cuylle still not expected at Peterborough Petes training camp
21.desc_api: Petes have no plans to trade him to another OHL club
21.caption_api: Peterborough Petes first-round draft pick Will Cuylle will not report to the Petes training camp when it opens on Monday and has yet to agree to even meet with Petes officials. The Petes have no plans to trade him to another OHL club.

22.title_api: Brooke Henderson two shots off lead after CP Women’s Open first round
22.desc_api: Mariajo Uribe, Ariya Jutanugarn and Nasa Hataoka were the clubhouse co-leaders at the LPGA Tour’s only Canadian stop.
22.caption_api: Ariya Jutanugarn of Thailand was tied for the lead after the first round of the CP Women’s Open in Regina on Thursday.

24.title_api: Hamilton Tiger-Cats face stiff test against Edmonton’s Mike Reilly
24.desc_api: Thursday’s Edmonton-Hamilton game could come down to whether the Tiger-Cats’ pass rush can disrupt Reilly, who hangs in the pocket longer than any quarterback in the CFL.
24.caption_api: Edmonton quarterback Mike Reilly comes in as the league’s top performe as his team prepares to visit the Hamilton Tiger-Cats on Thursday.

25.title_api: Ticats legend honoured: From the Hall to the Wall
25.desc_api: Joe Montford has never forgotten that 1996 spring day — his first moment, ever, in Canada — when he arrived at the Hamilton Tiger-Cats training camp.
25.caption_api: Montford hams it up while waiting for a team photo to be snapped.

26.title_api: Ticats tackle discipline in wake of bye week
26.desc_api: Nobody keeps statistics during practice, but a layman’s eye noticed Hamilton Tiger-Cats on both sides of the ball jumping offside a few too many times in Sunday’s return from their bye week.
26.caption_api: Assistant coach Orlondo Steinhauer works with players at Tim Hortons Field on Sunday. It was the first practice for the Tiger-Cats after a bye week.

27.title_api: Blue Bombers, Tiger-Cats get into head games
27.desc_api: Between Winnipeg coach Michael O’Shea and his penchant for special teams strategems and Hamilton coach June Jones’ run-and-shoot attack, each team has a lot to think about going into Friday night’s CFL showdown.
27.caption_api: Hamilton Tiger-Cats head coach June Jones fully expects the Winnipeg Blue Bombers, who are coming off of a bye week, “to do some funny things” on Friday.

28.title_api: Scouting report: Delvin Breaux a maybe for Ticats-Blue Bombers tilt
28.desc_api: Both Hamilton (3-4) and Winnipeg (4-3) are dealing with key injuries in their defensive coverage
28.caption_api: Defensive back Delvin Breaux, right, will be a game time decision after injuring himself in a collision with a teammate at practice earlier this week.

29.title_api: How seven Hamilton Tiger-Cats defensive backs became housemates
29.desc_api: After rookie defensive back Jackson Bennett found a place after training camp, teammates scrambling for accommodation all ended up living under the same Cannon Street roof.
29.caption_api: Seven Ticats defensive backs — from left to right, John Green, Jackson Bennett, Richard Leonard, Mariel Cooper, Frankie Williams, Jumal Rolle and Cariel Brooks — have rented a house together this season.

30.title_api: Second-chance Jalen Saunders on record-setting pace with Ticats
30.desc_api: The words come spilling out in a torrent, thoughts and ideas and emotions piled upon one another. He expresses the things that matter most — the challenges, the failures, the ultimate resurrection of his career with the Hamilton Tiger-Cats — with an uncommon intensity, with the perspective that comes from living with and learning from life’s mistakes.
30.caption_api: Hamilton Tiger Cats Jalen Saunders pulls down the ball in first quarter action on July 19, 2018.

31.title_api: Ticats look forward after drubbing of Johnny Manziel’s Alouettes
31.desc_api: Hamilton’s offence exploded Friday for five touchdowns while racking up more than 500 yards of offence
31.caption_api: Alouettes quarterback Johnny Manziel, left, is hit by Hamilton Tiger-Cats defensive end Jason Neill during first-quarter action in Montreal on Friday night.

32.title_api: Johnny Football and Alouettes get schooled by the Ticats
32.caption_api: Hamilton Tiger-Cats defensive end Justin Capicciotti and linebacker Simoni Lawrence celebrate a pass interception as Alouettes QB Johnny Manziel looks on during first-quarter Canadian Football League action in Montreal on Friday night. Manziel threw four interceptions in the first half.

44.title_api: Palestinian soccer head banned for inciting Messi hatred
44.desc_api: Palestinian soccer head banned for inciting Messi hatred
44.caption_api: FILE - In this Friday, May 29, 2015 file photo Jibril Rajoub, president of the Palestinian Football Association speaks during the 65th FIFA Congress held at the Hallenstadion in Zurich, Switzerland. FIFA has banned the head of the Palestinian Football Association from attending soccer games for a year for inciting hatred and violence toward Lionel Messi. Jibril Rajoub called on Arab soccer fans to burn Messi posters and shirts if he participated in an Argentina game in Israel in June. (Patrick B. Kraemer/Keystone via AP, File)

45.title_api: Hockey’s popularity heating up in Arizona desert
45.desc_api: When the Arizona Coyotes arrived from Winnipeg in 1996, hockey was a niche sport played by a couple thousand players at the state’s three ice rinks.
45.caption_api: The Coyotes will retire Shane Doan’s No. 19 on Feb. 24 when they face the Winnipeg Jets. Doan spent his entire 21-year career with the Coyotes before retiring prior to the 2017-18 season.

47.desc_api: Next Saturday night, racing followers will have the opportunity to see an entirely new face when New Zealand star Lazarus N contests the $600,000 Canadian Pacing Derby final at Woodbine Mohawk Park.
47.caption_api: Yannick Gingras drives Lazarus N to win the 25th running of the Dan Patch Stakes harness race at Hoosier Park in Anderson, Ind. Now, Lazarus looks to add the $615,000 Canadian Pacing Derby to his stellar racing resume.
